grammarNote.title: Transitive Actions with を
grammarNote.explanation: The particle を (pronounced 'o') marks the direct object — the thing being acted upon. With transitive verbs (verbs that take an object), the pattern is: [object]を[verb]. Examples: 船をつくる (make a boat), 話をきく (listen to a story), なにをたべる？ (What will [you] eat?). Japanese often drops the subject, so 食べる can mean 'I eat,' 'you eat,' or 'we eat' depending on context.

examples.japanese: なに を たべる？
パパ の 話 を きく。

vocabulary.example: パパ の 話 を きく。
あの 奴 は だれ だ？
きっと ほんとう だ。
だいじょうぶ だ よ。
そんな 奴 は ない。

storyNote: A clearing near the forest with a pitched tent. Campfire remnants. Backpacks and supplies. Moonlight through trees.
